content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Enoncé clair, variables bien définies, difficulté facile/moyenne, amusant, résultat correct

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Elle propose un travail intéressant sur les regexs. On ne pourra pas y échapper.

Testcases don't include a 100ml-199ml outlier.

Also, not at all feasible for reverse, as there are too many odd constraints that the player has to figure out without the goal description (the between 200-1000 and space/no space ml unit rules).

I think it's better to move both constraints to Goal section (with some rewording). While they do exhibit an element of "constraint", they contain important rules on how to identify the volume.

Thanks.

Thanks for your reply! I don't understand your 100ml-199ml outlier remark; the constraints are 200-1000, so indeed there is no case with 100-199.

As for reverse; I can remove that mode, but I do not agree right away with your comment, so let me state my opinion once. The space/no space and 200-1000 issue is something that fastest and shortest players need because they do not know what cases will be coming - but reverse players can simply see all the cases and find out that it is sometimes with and sometimes without space, and that all answers of the cases are between 200 and 1000. I've made sure that all validators are well between those boundaries (more than the test cases), so that a player does not get annoyingly surprised after submission.

Thanks for the approval. Even after Google translate I'm not fully sure (excuse my French): are you saying that this puzzle cannot be done without regex? Actually my solution code is without regex, because I am not so proficient in using it. But, probably it could be done much faster with regex; maybe I should set my mind to learning it better.

Thanks, according to Google translate you are positive about my puzzle :-).

I might start picking up some French next to coding with all those French comments going around.

With the 100ml thing, I was just saying that it would make sense to not allow the person to see 100ml as an answer, which some solutions, that just grab 3-4 digit numbers that have ml after them, might do and still pass all the cases.

I get your argument for the reverse cases. I think it would be nice if you make a test case that specifically shows the spaced ml and one specifically for the 200-1000 range.

Ex.

"Ingredients: Blah blah 500 ml and also 300 L of uh water"

"Ingredients: 100ml is not correct but 200ml is"


Also this is a unrelated comment but fastest and shortest players can see all the test cases that the reverse players can. I think they have to turn on dev mode or something and then you can click the test cases and see the inputs/outputs.

Ah, I now see your point about the ml case - I had totally overlooked that for the reverse player finding the value with 'ml' is not obvious. Instead of adding a test case that tries to explain this, I have altered the output request to [[volume]] {{ml}}.

As for the 200-1000 case, I did add an additional testcase with also values 150 and 180 in it. But I hesitated to put 150 ml in it, because then the border of 200 ml becomes more prominent, which is for reverse players quite arbitrary. And that is probably exactly what you meant as well. Let me think about it for a day - maybe I will remove reverse after all, and then indeed include a <200 ml edge case.

Thanks for taking your time to think along!

Update: I've removed the reverse mode, and changed the final test case into more of an edge case by including 150 ml, 180ml and 200ml in the text (of which 200 ml should be the answer based on the constraints).
